My first impressions are that this phone is fantastic in every aspect, performance, camera, battery life and charging speeds.

I also got a great deal getting a free pair of B&O headphones with it.
All i can say is i highly recommend anyone this phone, its great value for money.

author: @EdwardElric6464
comment_text: The USB trasfer speed is listed as USB 3.2 gen 1 which is only 5GB/s aka USB 3.0, however the phone can actually do USB 3.2 gen 2 speeds aka 3.1 or 10 GB/s. So it's as fast as the iPhone 15 pro or any modern Galaxy S phone. The Galaxy phones come with USB 2 cables so you need to use a better cable than what's in the box to get those speeds. These names are so confusing even oneplus got it wrong. It's why Apple said USB 3 10 gigabit for the 15 pro. 😢

author: @ElvenSpellmaker
comment_text:
I've upgraded from the OnePlus 11 and honestly it's a big upgrade like I've never felt before when upgrading each year.

The cameras are a _massive_ step up from the 11 every picture I've taken comes out so much better.

The back is finally not glossy! The OP 11 was a _nightmare_ to put down as the phone would just work it's way off almost any surface and onto the floor, I'm glad to see that go.

The rain feature is actually genuinely useful too.

I only keep my phone for a year so tons of years of updates isn't something I massively care about in a phone.

There's a fair amount of AI features, the rain detection stuff is AI for example, the photo editor has the object cutout feature too.

It's a fair bit heavier than the OP 11, slightly wider and taller, and the volume slider is _really_ high up on the right and hard to reach now, it's a shame they moved it.

author: @frankthetankricard
comment_text: I suspect you switch between dozens of phones in any single year so you don't have hands on experience with this but for people who want to keep their phones for years and years the limiting factor is the battery degradation. I am a very light user, only charging 2-3 times a week and mostly keeping the battery between 20 and 80 percent. Generally after 2.5 to 3 years my batteries start going downhill fast so I have to replace the phone. I've even tried buying the rare models with replaceable batteries but when I bought a new battery it's been sitting on a shelf so long in some warehouse that it was nearly as bad as the one I was replacing. So I don't care how long the software updates keep on coming after the phone is a useless brick. And I'd never look at a phone as a long term investment since it's engineered to be a consumable product.

author: @Plankton422
comment_text:
I have mine for a week now 16/512GB and it's insane.

Best screen i have seen so far even the edges don't change that. The battery is crazy 16hours screen on time is no problem. 26minutes from 0-100%

Connection is good even at places where i normally have bad signal. 

Performance is typical for the snapdragon 8 gen3. Oxygen os 14 is also a big upgrade to oos13.

The camera is one of the best on the market. There is less after editing on the pictures so they seem less vibrant but very realistic. With pro mode it's perfect for nearly every shot.

Front cam is basic but it's good. Nothing special.

The speakers are nice and the rumbles are the best I've felt so far. Even better then iPhone haptic feedback.

That all and more for less then 800€ is a perfect deal.

PS: they already launched oppo ai on china version so maybe in the near future there will be ai on oxygenOS too.

author: @Krozhin
comment_text:
Thank you for reviewing this phone Marques, i think it was absolutely the correct choice to do so.

When you first said you wouldn't review the OP12, it felt weird, because then you stray from the normalcy that is "expected".

People started wondering if you were at bad terms with 1+, some even claiming you were paid by the competition to not review it.

Nobody is entitled to the amazing, high quality content that you provide FOR FREE, but it would be nice for future reference to maybe use a community post on the main channel, or a short or something, should you decide not to review a product in the future for whatever reason, just so people don't get all conspiratorial.

The clip from the Waveform podcast was perfect but it had very little reach compared to your main videos, so i'm glad you took this route.

author: @leonaldobrum
comment_text:
I ordered mine yesterday, green, 16GB RAM, 512 GB Storage, and 2 covers... 1K Euros. Now, this year, that Samsung monster with comparable specs and accessories would cost me over 1.4 K€, just like the heavy S23 Ultra that I have and left in the drawer for excessive weight and size to carry. I already have the  OnePlus 11 and it's light, awesome in many ways. So you can see that 4-5 years of OS updates isn't that important for me. 
Which is the phone that you think will still be a joy to carry around with great battery, software stuff AND reliability that could compete with this  OnePlus mastery? I also have and use it!... The iPhone 15 Pro! And NOT that monster, the ProMax - super-expensive, unyielding, another heavy monster ... 
IMO, OnePlus top phones have several things going for them that are superb. They last long (my OnePlus One is still functional! As well are my 3, 5T, 7Pro, 9Pro and 10 Pro - besides my current 11). They all (except the 11, which is good) are weak in the camera department. The 11 got away with a much better camera experience, I'm expecting even better performance from my soon-to-arrive 12.

author: @RocketPunches
comment_text:
Honestly, your "no AI" downside is why I caved and bought this phone last week. To me, that's a massive, massive upside. To the point that for about the same price as the S23 I was thinking about buying, this was a no brainer. Maxed out hardware, no baked in AI bloatware that's going to age like a cracked egg on a summer sidewalk. I have not seen a single AI thing, on any device and especially not on phones, that looked good or seemed genuinely useful to me when compared to its downsides. If I can't trust that the transcription is accurate, it's useless. The image editing stuff, especially the magic eraser and generative fill stuff, looks so smeary and awful that I'm truly surprised you like it because I see it everywhere it's used like a massive beacon smacking me in the face. None of that stuff and a 40% price reduction? Yeah, count me in on that, seems great.

Also, for perspective on the support thing. I'm currently rolling with a Galaxy S8, that's a 7-8 year old phone. It's a bad experience in a lot of apps, its picture quality is, by modern standards, poor, it's battery life is poor (although maybe better than you'd expect), it simply cannot play a lot of games, and generally it has reduced my reliance on my phone in favor of my iPad Air 2 over the last couple years. Most people think it's crazy that I still have an S8 when they find out, and think it's weird. So I think OnePlus is probably right to suggest that number is mostly a marketing exercise and that 7 years of support does not mean 7 years of good user experience.

author: @KingdaGaertner
comment_text: I had the Oneplus One, which was great. However, when I got the Oneplus 6, it had many software related problems. The worst one was frequent stuttering when scrolling. Four years later, I gave the Oneplus 11 a chance, after seeing mostly positive reviews. I am disappointed as hell with this phone. The scrolling stutter is worse than ever, 120 Hz in all apps is only possible with a third party app that isn't even listed in the Play Store (at least this seems to be fixed now), and the clock on the always on display can not be disabled without disabling the always on display entirely, which just wastes battery life. Oneplus seems to ignore these issues despite being well aware of them. I will never buy a Oneplus phone again and wouldn't recommend them to anyone. The best hardware is useless, if the software is not up to par. Next time I will get a Pixel, a Samsung or an iPhone.

author: @grasz
comment_text:
I was gonna get this if I didn't get the Oneplus Open..
Switched from Note20 Ultra 5G.
The 12 is extremely good for the price. Only the iqoo pro or the red magic pro beats this in benchmark if that's your thing. S24 actually have a lower score in stress test or the long run. They have heat problems as the 12 uses some duo Cryo chamber that covers almost your whole phone to cool it without fans like those 2 I've mentioned. And they don't have 50w wireless charging and inferior cameras. This is the most bang for your buck you could get as a true flagship killer for $599 AND free upgrade to 512G. Helluva deal with specs.that will at least last you 4yrs of top hard & software support for $599 can't go wrong. Like my old Note20 Ultra 5G does everything a flagship today does. We still at 5G, vrr 120hz, 4k, HDR10+, bt s-pen, 8k vid, wifi 6, UWB, MST, 100x zoom, ultrasonic under display fingerprint sensor, Bluetooth 5.x..etc. you get the point.. still does it all. Get the 12 you won't regret it.

author: @turbyoulance
comment_text: When I was your age MKBHD , One Australian Dollar would buy $1.25 USA dollars. Now One Australian Dollar buys 65 USA cents. Think about that. So if a Phone cost $650USD , by the phone hits Australia it is at a price of $1,000 AUD. Then a 10% Goods and services charge added on $1,100 AUD. Then sales tax as well and then the Authorised dealer's have to take their cut. So we are paying like $1700 AUD and up for these phones. Example my SE2020 the $399 USD one cost me $829 AUD. All we ask of APPLE is to make them work .No overheating, no bendgate no drop out's no glitches, have SIRI Fit for Purpose (not useless) , be able to upgrade past IOS 17.0 (which my iPhone SE2020 refuses to do. ) Why can't the american's make something that works, instead of producing JUNK.? The trend now that we are in an inflationary environment is to Forget about the APPLE JUNK and buy the mid range ones or even the base models which do 95% of the Flagship things? That's why I will be reverting back to Android .Other than that , good synopsis on the Oneplus 12 phone , even though we don't stock it /them in Australia.

author: @tamwilfred
comment_text:
I believe the CEO mentioned that the company will only provide five years of support for their devices. Their reasoning is that after this period, the user experience might decline due to aging hardware. Personally, I find this explanation a bit lacking—it sounds like an excuse.

As a Note 20 Ultra user, I would continue using my device if it weren’t for the impending expiration of security patches next year and the enticing Samsung trade-in offers. I still own several flagship phones, and I’m confident that they could perform well with a newer operating system. The hardware in these devices is robust, and I believe they could remain functional for years with regular updates.

In a way, it reminds me of the PC cycle from the past. If smartphones follow a similar pattern, we might see longer lifespans for these devices, especially since recent hardware advancements haven’t been as dramatic as they were a decade ago.

author: @GodTamIt1
comment_text:
I have this phone and am about to return it.

It has little annoyances that stack up:
• Screen off battery drain is bad, around 1.8-2.3% per hour with the AOD, according to AccuBattery. 1.3% without AOD.
• The media player requires extra clicks to get to the scrubbing bar (when pulling down)
• The notifications have weird quirks. Marques talked about these last year. Clicking a collapsed stack of notifications doesn't open the app but just expands the stack.
• Gestures with 3rd party launchers have a terrible, long pause when swiping up to go home.

author: @the_indie_army
comment_text: The problem with the pricing this time around is OnePlus doesn't have any good carrier deals. I can get a Samsung Galaxy S24 Ultra for $300 after trade-in of pretty much any major device of the last 3-4 years. Even all the way back to a Galaxy S9 will get you $1000 trade-in credit on T-Mobile. With OnePlus 12, that's only going to get you $130 credit. So the OnePlus 12 ends up being a lot more expensive than the Galaxy S24 Ultra when all is said and done. I felt it was a bit disingenuous the mention the OnePlus' current trade-in deals, but not the Samsung's. Which makes even the S24 Ultra a cheaper phone.

author: @dr.fitprofessor4363
comment_text:
Frankly, the term flagship killer is somewhat subjective these days. That being said, the OnePlus 12 is a legitimate flagship. If you're looking for a flagship killer then you should really look at the OnePlus 12R. As far as OnePlus is concerned, gone are the days of terms such as Pro, Plus and Ultra. I find the new simplistic way their classifying their devices to be a great idea. 
Strictly speaking, I've never really found a problem with their cameras since their involvement with hasselblad. The big problem with many people is that they're used to the point and shoot of an iphone. The same people pick up a OnePlus device with a hasselblad and they don't know how to use the camera application. It takes time to learn and once you do the photos are amazing. This is the same issue with Sony devices.

author: @logicalparadox2897
comment_text:
If this phone was IP68, i would be all in. But no. For some reason they can't just release a pro version with IP68 and a few other small upgrades to make it more premium?

I guess I'm still stuck on my 9 Pro. I don't get why the whole "OnePlus is back" narrative it's completely centered on price. I don't want a flagship killer, I just want a flagship that isn't Samsung or Apple. For software reasons. And the pixel has never appealed to me sadly.

The fast charging, rate screen, great battery life. I'm here for it. But what's saving a couple hundred bucks over the course of a couple of years if I have to worry that one day I'm going to drop my phone into the bathtub or the sink or a puddle. The peace of mind factor is huge. It's not just about the cost of a dead phone, because you can get insurance for that. It's about now your phone is dead. Wherever you are whatever you were doing you no longer have a phone until you can put in a claim and get a new one sent out. That's a real bummer at your pool party or your fun day at the beach. And it makes that stressful evening where you're rushing to get the dishes done because you got home from work late into A much worse experience when your phone slips out of your wet hands and disappears under the suds and comes back up lifeless.
